Title: Behavioral effects of triadimefon in zebrafish are associated with alterations of the dopaminergic and serotonergic pathways

  - "5 dpf larvae were incubated in 96-well multiwell plates with 200 μL of TDF ranging from 5 mg/L to 35 mg/L at room temperature (23-26 °C) for 10 h under constant illumination. Co-incubations of TDF 35 mg/L with SCH-23390 or Haloperidol at 8 μM were also performed."

Title: Carbofuran induces increased anxiety-like behaviors in female zebrafish (Danio rerio) through disturbing dopaminergic/ norepinephrinergic system
Authors: Shuang Liu, Miao Yu, Xincen Xie, Yiran Ru, Shaoguo Ru, David Volz
Supporting quotes for "Study type":
- "After 48 h, fish were used for anxiety-like behavioral tests and related gene expression analysis."
  - "Inhibitor of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), a-Methyltyrosine (AMPT, Aladdin, Shanghai, China), was used to confirm the role of TH in carbofuran-induced anxiety-like behaviors, through intraperitoneal injection method described by Kinkel et al. (2010)."
Reasoning for "Study type":
The study type appears to be experimental based on the following evidence from the paper:
"Carbofuran (CAS NO: 1563-66-2, purity !98.8%) was purchased from the Shanghai Pesticide Research Institute (Shanghai, China). Carbofuran was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) to obtain a 10 mg/mL stock solution, which was further used to prepare the fresh diluted solution (500 mg/mL) during the exposure experiment. The exposure experiments were conducted in 5-L glass tanks filled with 4 L of carbofuran exposure or solvent control medium, each tank contained 6 female zebrafish."
This quote indicates that the researchers conducted a controlled exposure experiment where they exposed zebrafish to different concentrations of carbofuran.
"Inhibitor of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), a-Methyltyrosine (AMPT, Aladdin, Shanghai, China), was used to confirm the role of TH in carbofuran-induced anxiety-like behaviors, through intraperitoneal injection method described by Kinkel et al. (2010)."
This quote further confirms the experimental nature of the study, as the researchers used a pharmacological intervention (AMPT injection) to test a specific hypothesis about the mechanism of carbofuran's effects.
"After 48 h, fish were used for anxiety-like behavioral tests and related gene expression analysis."
This quote indicates that the researchers measured behavioral and molecular outcomes in the zebrafish after the exposure period, which is characteristic of an experimental study design.

Title: The organophosphate insecticide diazinon and aging: Neurobehavioral and mitochondrial effects in zebrafish exposed as embryos or during aging

- "All zebrafish care and husbandry procedures were approved by the Duke University Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee"
  - "Doses within each study were selected based on prior tolerability studies, which identified the lowest overtly toxic dose of DZN at each age and set out three doses, separated by ½ log units, decending from a high, sub-lethal/dysmorphogenic dose."
  - "One group of 14-month-old adult ZF were exposed acutely as adults (0.4, 1.25, and 4.0 μM) for five days and tested as adults, and another group was exposed developmentally 5-120 h post-fertilization (70, 210, and 700 nM) and tested at larval, adolescent, adult, and aging life stages."

The study type is experimental. This can be determined from several quotes in the paper:

This quote indicates that the researchers conducted two separate studies, one exposing adult zebrafish to diazinon and another exposing zebrafish during development.

Title: Tributyltin enhanced anxiety of adult male zebrafish through elevating cortisol level and disruption in serotonin, dopamine and gamma-aminobutyric acid neurotransmitter pathways
Authors: Xin Tu, Ying-Wen Li, Qi-Liang Chen, Yan-Jun Shen, Zhi-Hao Liu
Reasoning for "Study type":
The study type is experimental. This is evident from several quotes in the paper:
After domestication, 54 uniform-sized (0.32 ± 0.06 g) male fish were randomly selected. The fish were then separated into 3 groups (Control, 0.05% DMSO; TBT-low, 100 ng/L and TBT-high, 500 ng/L) with triplicate tanks (50 cm × 25 cm × 30 cm, containing 6 individuals in 20 L exposure water per tank) per group. The fish were then exposed to corresponding concentrations of TBT for 28 days with a 14 h/10 h light/ darkness photoperiod and fed with Artemia nauplii (Artemia International LCC, USA) and flake food daily (1.5% body weight per day) during exposure.
This quote describes how the researchers randomly assigned the fish to different treatment groups and exposed them to varying concentrations of TBT, which is a clear experimental design.
After exposure, the novel tank dive test was conducted following the method provided by Egan et al. (2009). Briefly, the test tank (15 cm × 20 cm × 25 cm) with 10 cm water was divided equally into two parts (lower and upper) by drawing a horizontal line (5 cm from the bottom) through the center of the water column prior to the test. Three fish from each tank (9 fish for each group; N = 9) was then placed into the test tank individually.
This quote further describes the experimental procedure of the novel tank dive test, which was used to assess the anxiety-like behavior of the fish.
